title: NASPGHAN position statement: Enabling quality pediatric gastroenterology care through electronic health record data capture and visualization.
abstract: Clinical practice guidelines are structured recommendations, derived from evidence-based research, aiming to inform, improve, and standardize patient care. This position paper considers the critical role the electronic health record (EHR) plays in data collection and implementation of guidelines. We describe EHR functionalities necessary to make guidelines actionable within the EHR and provide overview of data storage to inform design of data capture tools to reduce overall clinician workload. After reviewing current knowledge and practices, we have formulated the recommendation that NASPGHAN committees should develop clinical guidelines that identify specific and relevant health assessment measures with strong validity evidence, including patient-reported outcome measures. Guidelines should also outline clinical pathways, incorporating clinical decision support algorithms to provide feedback to users, and order sets to ensure the right guidance is provided for the right patient at the right time. Patient populations should be defined by using standard code sets. Committees should identify disease-specific health assessment measures with strong validity of evidence and identify areas where measures are still needed. Committees should offer guidance on population-based disease management and data visualization tools.
authors: Lee JA; Miller S; Walsh CM; Mehta K; Watson KL; Hayes CE; Sauer C; Huang JS
first_author_affiliation: Divisions of Pediatric Gastroenterology Hepatology and Nutrition and Clinical Informatics, Department of Pediatrics and Biomedical Informatics, Nationwide Children's Hospital, The Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio, USA.

title: Predictive modeling for early detection of refractory esophageal stricture following esophageal atresia surgery: insight from a machine learning study.
abstract:
Background

Refractory esophageal stricture (RES) presents a challenging complication after esophageal atresia (EA) repair. Earlier identification of patients with RES could help clinical decision-making. However, there are currently limited articles to predict the occurrence of RES after EA repair.

Methods

All patients diagnosed with esophageal strictures (ES) who underwent primary endoscopic balloon dilations (EBD) after EA repair in our institution between January 2017 to December 2022 were retrospectively reviewed. They were divided into two groups according to the presence or absence of suffering RES to analyze the risk factors for developing RES after EA repair and construct a predictive model using the machine learning (ML) method, based on the baseline characteristics, early postoperative complications, and ES features at the first EBD.

Results

92 patients were included in our study, including the RES group (n = 59) and the non-RES group (n = 33). In terms of patient demographics, multivariate analysis revealed that LGEA (p = 0.021), and anastomosis leak (p = 0.016) were the risk factors for developing RES after EA repair. Further analysis of the stricture characteristics after EA repair between the two groups revealed that esophageal stricture at a two-thirds lower level (p = 0.006), eccentric esophageal stenosis (p = 0.048), and a higher upper pouch stricture index (U-SI) (p = 0.011) emerged as significant risk factors for developing RES following EA repair. Then, we constructed ML models for predicting RES following LEAP based on patient demographics and stricture characteristics. Among all the ML models, the decision tree (DET), random forest (RF), and multilayer perceptron (MLP) models demonstrated perfect predictive value in the validation set. Among them, the RF model showed the highest average AUC in the training set (AUC = 0.756, 95% CI: 0.584-0.928), indicating better reproducibility. Subsequently, we used Shapley additive explanation (SHAP) to interpret the most important features and found that U-SI, rTEF, stricture level, and anastomotic leakage were identified as the most important predictive features. Furthermore, an RF-based clinical decision support system was deployed, providing dynamic visualization for predicting RES.

Conclusion

LGEA, anastomosis leak, lower stricture level, eccentric stricture, and higher U-SI value were risk factors for RES after EA repair. By utilizing the ML predictive model, we could efficiently and accurately predict the occurrence of RES.
authors: Xie C; Wang D; Wang A; Zhao Y; Liao J; Zhang Y; Hua K; Gu Y; Du J; Sun D; Guo J; Li S; Huang J
first_author_affiliation: Department of Neonatal Surgery, Beijing Childrens Hospital, Capital Medical University, National Center for Children's Health, No. 56 Nalishi Road, Xicheng District, Beijing, 100045, China.
matched_keywords: visualization(abstract); visual(abstract); machine learning(kw,title,abstract); clinical decision support(abstract)
api_keywords: Predictive model; Machine Learning; Refractory Esophageal Strictures

title: The State of Single-Cell Atlas Data Visualization in the Biological Literature.
abstract: Recent advancements have enabled tissue samples to be profiled at the unprecedented level of detail of a single cell. Analysis of this data has enabled discoveries that are relevant to understanding disease and developing therapeutics. Large-scale profiling efforts are underway which aim to generate 'atlas' resources that catalog cellular archetypes including biomarkers and spatial locations. While the problem of cellular data visualization is not new, the size, resolution, and heterogeneity of single-cell atlas datasets presents challenges and opportunities. We survey the usage of visualization to interpret single-cell atlas datasets by assessing over 1,800 figure panels from 45 biological publications. We intend for this report to serve as a foundational resource for the visualization community as atlas-scale single-cell datasets are emerging rapidly with aims of advancing our understanding of biological function in health and disease.
authors: Keller MS; Morth E; Smits TC; Warchol S; Guo G; Wang Q; Krueger R; Pfister H; Gehlenborg N

title: Improving personalized healthcare with automated longitudinal EHR analysis.
abstract:
Background

Traditional Electronic Health Record (EHR) data analysis at King's College Hospital relies on extensive manual effort, from data extraction to reporting, limiting efficiency and scalability. This study presents an automated framework for longitudinal EHR data analysis to enhance personalized healthcare insights.

Methods

Central to the framework is the integration of Markov Chains with Survival Analysis (SA) and Latent Growth Modeling, enhancing the modeling of patient trajectories and capturing variances in growth patterns over time. Expectation-Maximization with Gaussian Mixture Models, extended with Latent Class Analysis, identifies clinically meaningful patient subgroups for tailored interventions. The framework addresses data uncertainty, enabling precise event forecasts and trajectory predictions. The system employs Apache NiFi for data ingestion, Elasticsearch for indexing, and Splunk and Kibana for real-time visualization and reporting. Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques extract structured insights from unstructured clinical notes, enriching datasets with context. The automation significantly reduces manual processing while ensuring data integrity and enhancing predictive capabilities.

Main findings

Implementation demonstrated a 15% increase in detecting major depression cases, an 18% improvement in predicting patient decisions, a 25% reduction in growth trajectory prediction variance, and a 10% increase in event prediction accuracy. The framework enhances data-driven decision-making, supporting personalized healthcare interventions through real-time insights.

Conclusions

This automated framework integrates predictive modeling, NLP techniques, and real-time data processing, improving the efficiency and accuracy of longitudinal EHR analysis. Providing robust, actionable insights enables personalized healthcare delivery, enhances clinical decision-making, and optimizes patient outcomes.
authors: Pal G
first_author_affiliation: Department of Clinical Neuroscience, Institute of Psychiatry, Psychology and Neuroscience, King's College London, London, UK; Indian Institute of Management Ranchi, Ranchi, Jharkhand 835303, India. Electronic address: gautam.pal@iimranchi.ac.in.
